enimies brother hym queene lord hir bloud highly maligned king kinred woman commonly malice nature hate husbandes loue proude appetite duke hymselfe intending king least wise heinous treaso laid charge finally faultie faultlesse attaynted parliament iudged death therevpon hastily drowned butte malmesey whose death king edward albeit commaunded wyst done piteously bewayled sorowfully repented richarde thirde sonne wee nowe intreatethe discription richard third wit courage egall either body prowes farre vnder little stature yll featured limmes crooke backed left shoulder much hygher right hard fauoured visage state called warlye men otherwise malicious wrathfull enuious afore byrth euer froward truth reported dutch mother much doe hir trauaile yt coulde deliuered vncut came world feete forward borne outward ye fame runneth also vntoothed whether hatred report aboue ye truth else nature chauged hir course beginning course life many thing vnnaturally committed none euil captaine ye warre dispotio meetely tha peace sundry victory somtimes ouerthrows neuer default person either hardines politike order free called dispence somewhat aboue power liberall wt large giftes gat vnstedfast friendship faine pill spoile place get stedfast hatred close secrete deepe dissimuler lowly countenaunce arrogant heart outwardlye coumpinable inwardlye hated letting kisse hee thought kill dispiteous cruell euill wil alway ofter ambition either fuertie increase estate friend foe much indifferent aduauntage grewe spared man death whose life wythstoode purpose slewe owne handes king henry sixt prisoner tower menthe death king henrie sixte constantly said without commaundement knowledge king would vndoubtedly intended thing haue appointed butcherly office owne borne brother wise men also ween drift couertly conueyed lacked helping forth brother clarence death resisted openly howbeit somewhat men deemed faintly hartily mynded wealth thus deeme thinke long time k edwardes lyfe forethought king case king brother whose life looked euill diet shorten happen deceasse deede child yong deeme intent glad brother death ye duke clarence whose life must needes haue hindered intending whether duke clarence kept true nephew yong king enterprised king himselfe al poynt certaintie deuineth vpon coniectures may aswell shoote farre short howbeit haue credible information learned selfe night king edward dyed one mistlebrooke long ere morning came great hast house one pottier dwelling redcrosse streete without creplegate loxdon hastie rapping quicklye letten shewed vnto pottier king edwarde departed truth man quoth pottier maister duke glocester king cause thinke harde say whether toward thing knewe thing purposed otherwise inkeling thereof likely speake nought returne course historie duke gloucester hadde olde foreminded conclusion nowe erste therevnto moued putte hope occasion tender age yong prince nephewes oportunitie likelihoode speede putteth man courage neuer intended certaine contriued destruction vsurpation regall dignitie vpon himselfe forasmuche well wiste holpe maintaine long continued grudge heartburning betwene queenes kinred king bloude either partie enuying others aucthoritie nowe thought diuision shoulde indeede furtherly beginning pursuit hys intent sure ground foundation al building might firste vnder pretexte reuenging old displeasure abuse anger ignorance one partie destruction winne hys purpose many coulde could bee wonne myght lost ere looked therefore one thing certayne hys intent perceyued soone haue made peace betweene party owne bloud king edwarde life albeit dissention betweene friendes somewhat irked yet good health somewhat lesse regarded bicause thought whatsoeuer businesse shoulde fall betweene himselfe alway able rule party last sicknesse whe perceiued naturall strength sore enfeebled dispaired al recouerie considering youth child albeit nothing lesse mistrusted happened yet well foreseeing many harmes might growe debate youthe child lacke discretion themselues good counsell friendes either partie counsell owne commoditie rather pleasaunt aduise wyn themselues fauour profitable aduertisement doo child good called variaunce especiall lord marque dorset queenes sonne hir first husbande william lord hastings noble man lord chamberlaine againe queene specially grudged great fauour king bare also thought secretly familiar king wanto company hir kinred also bare sore aswell king made captaine calleis office lord riuers brother queene claimed king former promise diuers great gift receiued looked lord diuers party come presence king lifting vp himselfe vnderset pyllows reported wise saide vnto lordes deare kin men alies plight lie youthe oration king death bed see fee e lesse looke lo liue deepely moued care case leaue leaue childre like finde god forbid finde variaunce might hap fall theselues warre ere discretion would serue set peace ye see youth recken onely suertie rest concorde suffiseth loue eche hate faithfulnes happily would suffise childhood must maintained men aucthority slipper youth vnderpropped wt elder cousel neither ca haue ye giue ye giue ye gree eche laboureth breake maketh hatred eche others person impugneth eche others cousell must needes long ere good conclusion go forward also either party laboreth chief flatterie shal haue place tha plaine faithfull aduise must needes insue ye euil bringing vp prince whose minde teder youth infect shal redily fal mischief riot draw downe noble realme ruine grace turne wisdome god send euil meanes pleased best shal fal furthest fauour euer length euil drift draw nought good plaine wayes prosper great variaunce hath long bene betweene alway great cause sometime thing right wel intended misconstructio turneth vnto worse small displeasure done v either owne affectio euil tongue agreeueth wot well ye neuer great cause hatred ye haue loue al men christen shal leaue preacher tell yet wot neare whether preacher word ought moue tha going place al preache shal desire remeber one part bloud mine alies ech either kinred affinitie spiritual kinred affinitie sacramentes christes church beare weight v would god lesse moue v charitie ye respect fleshly consanguinitie lord forbid loue togither ye worse selfe cause ye ought loue ye better yet happeneth finde deadly debate among nature lawe ought agree togither pestilent serpent ambitioambition desire vaine glory soueraintie amog state entreth creepeth forth farre til wt deuision variaunce turneth mischiefe first longing next best afterward egall best last chiefe aboue best immoderate appetite worship thereby debate dissentio losse sorowe trouble hath wt yeeres grown realme pray god aswel forget wel remeber thing could aswel haue foreseen haue wt paine pleasure proued godes blessed lady euer othe would neuer haue courtesie men knee wt losse many head sithen thing passed cannot gainecalled much ought beware occasion haue taken great hurt afore eft soones fall occasion againe grief passed god thanked quiet likely right well prosper wealthfull peare vnder cousin child god send life loue two thing lesse losse though god pleasure yet realme alway finde king peraduenture good king among selues childes raigne fall debate many good man shall perish haply ye ere land finde peace againe wherfore last wordes euer looke speake exhorte require loue haue euer borne mee loue haue euer borne vnto loue lord beareth v time forward griefes forgotten eche loue verely trust ye thing earthly regarde eyther god king affinitie kinred realme owne countrey owne suertie therewithall king longer induring sit vp laid downe ryghte side face toward none present could refraine weeping lordes recomforting good wordes could answering time thought stand pleasure presence theyr wordes appeared eche forgaue ioyned handes together appeared deedes harte farre sunder soone king departed noble prince sonne drew toward london time deceasse kept housholde ludlowe wale countrey beeing farre lawe recourse justice begon farre good waxen wylde robber reuers walking libertie vncorrected encheason prince life father sent thither eude au thoritie presence shoulde refraine euill disposed person fro boldenesse former outrage gouernaunce orderyng yog prince sending thither appointed sir anthonie wood ile lorde riuers brother vntolord riuers queene right honorable man valiant hande politike counsell adioyned vnto partie effect euery one nearest kinne vnto queene planted nexte aboute prince drifte queene vnwisely deuised wherby hir bloude might youth rooted prince fauor duke glocester tourned vnto theyr destruction vpon grounde sette foundation vnhappye building soeuer perceyued eyther variaunce bearing himselfe fauour brake vnto mouth writing secret messenger neyther reason wise bee suffered yong king theyr maister kinsman shoulde handes custodie mother kinred sequestered maner theyr companye attendaunce whiche euerye one ought faithful seruice many farre honorable parte kinne hys mother side whose bloud quoth sauing king pleasure full vnmeetelye matched hys whiche nowe saye remoued fro king lesse noble left quoth neyther honorable maiestie vnto v also hys grace suretie haue mightiest friend vnto v little ieopardie suffer oure well proued euill willers growe ouer great auctority wyth prince youth namely light beliefe soone perswaded yee remember trowe king edward himselfe albeit manne age discretion yet hee manye thing ruled bende stoode eyther wyth hys honour profitte commoditie man else excepte onely immoderate aduancemente themselues whether sort thir ted owne weale wo harde wene gesse folkes friendship holden better place king respect kinred might peraduenture easilye haue betrapped brought confusion v ere easilye haue done alreadye neere royall bloude wee lorde hath wrought thankes grace peril past howbeit great growing suffer yog king enemy without witting might abuse name hys commaundement vndoing thing god good prouision forbidde whiche good prouision none v hath thing lesse neede late made attonement king pleasure hadde place party willes none v beleeue vnwise ouersoone truste newe friend made old foe thinke hourely kindenes sodainly contracte one houre continued yet skant fortnight deeper settled stomacke long accustomed malice manye yeares rooted wordes writing suche duke glocester soone set fire themselues eathe kindle especial twayne edwarde duke bu kingham wiliam lord hastings chamberlain men honour great power tone long succession auncestrie tother office king fauour two beryng eache muche lone hatred vnto queenes parte point accorded togither wyth duke glocester would vtterly amoue king company hys mother friendes vnder name theyr enimies uppon concluded duke gloucester vnderstanding lordes whyche time king intended bring vp coronation accompanied suche power friend harde bring purpose passe without gathering greate assemble people manner open warre whereof ende wiste doubtfull whiche king side part haue face name rebellion secretly therfore diner meanes caused queene perswaded broughte minde neyther neede also shoulde ieopardous king come vppe strong whereas nowe euerye lorde loued none thing studyed vppon aboute coronation honor king lordes hir kyndred shoulde assemble king name muche people shoulde giue lordes wixte hadde bin sometime debate feare suspect leaste shoulde gather people king safegarde whome man impugned destruction hauing regarde theyr olde variaunce newe attonement cause assemble partie much people againe theyr defence whose power wiste wel farre stretched thus shoulde realme fall ore hurte thereof shoulde ensue likely little moste harme lyke fall leaste woulde worlde woulde put hyr hyr kyndred wight saye hadde vnwisely vntruely also broken amitie peace kyng hyr usbande prudentlye made betweene kinne hyrs death bed partie faithfully obserued queene wise perswaded suche worde sente vnto hir sonne vnto hir brother beeing aboute kyng ouer duke glocester hymselfe lordes chiefe bende wrote vnto king reuerentlye queenes friendes louingly nothing earthly mistrusting brought king vp greate haste good speede sober companye king hys waye london gone northampton duke glocester buckingham came thither remained behinde lord riuers king vncle intending morrowe followe king stonie stratforde xij myles thence earelye departed made nighte muche friendlye cheare betweene two duke lord riuers great whyle incontinent openlye greate curtesie departed lorde riuers lodged duke secretely fewe theyr moste priuie friendes set counsaile wherein spent great parte nighte theyr rising dawning day sente priuilye theyr seruantes theyr innes lodging giuing commaundement make theselues shortly readie lordes horssebackewarde uppon whyche message manye theyr folke attendaunt manye lord riuers seruauntes vnreadye nowe duke taken also theyr custody keyes inne none shoulde passe forth without licece ouer thys highe waye towarde stonie stratforde king laye hadde bestowed certaine theyr folke shoulde sende backe againe compell returne anye man gotten northampton towarde stonie stratforde tyll shoulde giue licence much duke theselues inteded shew theyr diligence firste shoulde daye attende vpon king highnesse towne thus bare folke hande lord riuers vnderstoode gate closed wayes euery side beset neyther seruauntes himselfe suffered goe perceiuing wel great thing without knowledge begun naughte comparing thys manner present wyth hys last night cheere fewe houres great change maruellously misliked howbeit sith coulde gette awaye keepe himselfe close would least seeme hyde secrete fear fault wherof saw cause hymself determined vpon suretie conscience go boldelie inquire matter mighte meane whome one sawe beganne quarrel saye intended set distaunce betweene kyng bring confusion lye hys power beganne wel spoken man goodly wise excuse himselfe tarryed ende aunsweare shortly tooke hymthe l riuers put vvarde put warde done forthwyth wente horssebacke tooke waye stonie stratforde founde king wyth hys companye readie leape horssebacke depart forwarde leaue lodging bycause straighte companyes soone came hys presece light adown companye duke buckingham sayd go afore gentleman yeoman keepe roomes thus goodly aray came king theyr knee verye humble wyse salued grace whiche receyued ioyous amiable maner nothing earthlye knowing mistrusting yet euen presence piked quarrell lorde rycharde lord grey gray king brother mother saying lorde marque brother lorde riuers uncle compassed rule king realme set variance among state subdue destroye noble bloude realme toward accomplishing whereof sayd lorde marque entred tower london thence taken kyngs treasure sente menne sea thing duke wist well done good purpose necessarie whole counsaile london sauing somewhat must say unto word king aunswered brother marque hath done cannot saye good faith dare well aunsweare mine vncle riuers brother innocent suche matter yea liege quoth duke buckingham haue kept theyr dealing matter farre fro knowledge good grace forthwyth arested lord richard sir th vaugha knight king presence brought king al back vnto northampton tooke againe counsell sent away fro king pleased set new seruaunts liked better dealing wept nothing content booted dinner duke glocester sente dishe owne table lord riuers praying good cheare well ynough thanked duke prayed messenger beare nephew lord richard message hys comforte one whome aduersitie strage himselfe bin dayes vre therewith therfore could beare better cofortable curtesie duke glocester sent lord riuers thethe death l riuers others lord richarde sir thomas vaughan northe countrey diuerse place prison afterwarde pomfraite conclusion beheaded wise duke glocester toke vppon hymselfe order gouernaunce yong king muche honoure humble reuerence hee conueyed vpward toward citie anone tydings matter came hastily queene little midnighte following sorest wise king hir son taken hir brother hir sonne friend arrested sente man wist whether bee done god wot tydings queene great flight heauinesse bewayling hir childes raigne hir friendes mischaunce hir owne infortune damning time euer disswaded gathering power aboute kyng gatte hyr selfe haste possible wyth hir yo ger sonne hyr daughter pallaice westminster whiche laye sanctuariethe qu taketh sanctuarie lodging hyr selfe hyr companye abbot place came one likewise long midnighte lorde chamberlayne vnto archbishoppe yorke chancellour englande place far fro westminster shewed seruauntes hee tydings great importaunce hys maister gaue charge forbeare reste letted wake admitte messenger bedde side whome hearde duke gone backe wyth king grace stonie stratforde vnto northampton notwythstanding syr quoth lorde sendeth lordshippe worde feare assureth shall well assure quoth archebishoppe well wyll neuer well haue seene therevpon messenger departed caused haste sernauntes called vp owne housholde euerye man weaponed tooke greate seale came yet daye vnto queene founde much heauinesse rumble hast businesse cariage conueyaunce hyr stuffe sanctuarie chestes coffer packes fardel trussed men backes man vnoccupied lading going discharging comming breaking walles bring next way yet drewe helpe carry wrong way queene hir selfe sate alone alowe rush al desolate dismayde whome archebishoppe comforted beste manner coulde shewing hir trusted matter nothing sore toke putte good hope feare ye message sent lord chamberlaine ah wo worth hym quoth one laboureth destroye bloud madam quoth yee good cheere assure crowne king son nowe haue shall morrowe crowne hys brother haue greate seale whyche likewise noble prince husbande deliuered vnto heere deliuer vnto vse behoofe sonne therewith betooke hir greate seale departed home againe yet dawning daye whiche time mighte chamber windowe see thamis full boates duke glocesters seruauntes watching man shoulde go sanctuarie none could passe vnsearched great commotion murmur well place specially citie people diuersly diuining vpo deling lord knightes gentleman eyther fauour queen feare themselues assembled sundry company wente flockmeale harneys manye also reckoned thys demeanour attempted speciallye lord king himselfe disturbaunce coronation lordes assembled togither towarde whiche meeting archbishoppe yorke fearing woulde ascribed indeede ouermuch lightnesse suddainely hadde yeelded vppe greate seale queene custodie thereof nothing perteyned wythout speciall commaundement king secretely sent seale againe brought customable manner meeting lorde hasting whose trouth toward ye king man doubted needed doubt perswaded lordes beleeue duke glocester sure fastly faithfull prince lord riuers lorde richarde knightes matter attempted duke glocester buckingham put vnder arest suretie king ieopardie also safegarde longer shoulde remayne till matter duke onely also lord ye king counsayle indifferently examyned discretion ordered eyther iudged appeased one thing aduised beware iudged matter farre forth ere knew trueth turning theyr priuate grudge common hurte yrking prouoking men vnto anger disturbing king coronation toward duke coming vp might peraduenture bring matter farre ioynte shoulde neuer broughte frame againe whiche strife happe lykely come fielde though party thing equal yet shoulde aucthoritie side king himselfe perswasions lord hastings whereof part himselfe beleeued parte wist contrarie commotion somwhat appeased specially duke glocester buckingha wer neere came shortly king none manner none voyce semblance coronation causing fame blowen lord knight taken contriued destruction duke glocester buckingham noble bloud realme end selues would alone demeane gouern king pleasure coulourable proofe therof duke seruauntes rode carte stuffe taken among stuffe maruel thoughe harneys breaking vppe housholde must needes eyther brought awaye cast away shewed vnto people wayes went loe heere rels harneys traytours hadde priuilye conueyed theyr carriage destroy noble lordes withal deuise albeit made matter wise men vnlikely well perceyuing intendours purpose would rather haue hadde theyr harneys backes haue bound vppe barrel yet much part commo people therwith wel satisfied sayd almoyse hang king approched neere citie edmonde shaa goldsmith maior william white iohn matthew sherifes al alderman scarlet fiue hundered horsse citizen violet receyued reuerently harnesey ryding thence accompanyedthe king co ming londo citie whiche entred fourth daye maye first laste yeare raigne duke gloucester bare hym open sight reuerently prince semblaunce lowlinesse great obloquie late sodainly fallen gret trust ye counsel next assebled made chose thought meete protector ye king hys realme thatthe protectour made destenie follie lambe betaken woolfe keepe whych counsayle also archbyshop yorke chauncelor englande whyche hadde delyuered vppe greate seale queene thereof greately reprooued seale taken hym delyuered doctor russell byshoppe lincolne wisethe bishop lincolne made lord chauncellour man good muche experience one beste learned menne vndoubtedly englande hys time dyuers lordes knightes appointed vnto dyuers roumes lorde chamberlaine kepte still theyr office nowe protector sore thirsted finishing begunne thought euery daye yeare till atcheeued yet durste hee attempte long halfe hys pray hande well witting deposed one brother realme woulde fall hee either remayned sanctuarie shoulde happily shortelye conueyed hys father libertie wherfore incontinent nexte meeting lordes counsaile proposed vnto hainous deede queenthe protectours oration proceeding greate malice towarde kyngs counsailours shoulde keepe sanctuarie king brother hym whose speciall pleasure comforte haue brother hym hir done none intente bring lordes obloquie murmure people thoughe trusted king brother assente noble lande appointed king nearest friendes tuition hys owne royall person prosperitie whereof standeth quoth keeping enimies ill vyande partly also recreation moderate pleasure whiche cannot hys tenuer youth take companye auncient person familiar conuersation neither far vnder farre aboue age naythelesse estate conuenient accompanye hys noble maiestie wherefore whome rather wyth hys owne brother anye man thinke consideration whyche thinke manne thinketh loueth king let consider sometyme wythout small thing greater cannot stande verilye redoundeth greatlye dishonour king hyghnesse v bene aboute grace haue runne euerye man mouth realme also land euil word walke far ye king brother shold fain kepe sactuary euery wil weene ye wil nought euil opinio fastned men heart hard wraste may grow grief tha deuine wherfore thinketh worst send vnto q redresse matter honorable trustie man suche tendereth kyngs weale honoure hys counsayle also fauour credence wyth hyr consideration none seemeth meetely reuerende father heere present lord cardinall maye matter doe good man please take payne doubt hys goodnesse refuse king sake wealth yong duke king honorable brother soueraigne lord himselfe deere nephew considered thereby shal ceassed slaunderous rumor obloquie nowe going hurtes au yded thereof mighte ensue muche reste quiet growe realme percase obstinate precisely set vpon hir wil neyther wise faithful aduertisement moue hir anye mannes reason contente hir shall mine aduise king authoritie fetche prison bring hym hys noble presence whose continuall companye shall well cheerished honorablye intreated al world shal honor hir reproche perceyue onely malice frowardenesse follie caused hir keepe minde matter time except lordshippes thing perceiue contrarie neuer shall god grace wedde selfe mine owne wil shal readie change vpon better aduises protectoure hadde sayde counsayle affirmed motion good reasonable king duke brother honorable thing cease greate murmure realme mother mighte good meanes enduced deliuer thing archbishop yorke agreed also thereto conuenient tooke vpon moue hir therin doe vttermost deuoire howbeit coulde wise intreated hyr good deliuer thought spiritualtie present wise attempted take hir wil would besanctuarie thing shoulde turne greate grudge men high displeasure god priuiledge holye place shoulde nowe broken whiche many yeares bene kepte king pope good gra ted many hadde confirmed holy ground fiue hundred yeares agoe saint peter hys owne person spirite accompanyed wyth great multitude angel night speciallye hallowed dedicate god proofe whereof haue yet abbay peter cope shewe time hitherward ther neuer vndeuoute king durst sacred place violate holy byshop durst presume consecrate therefore quoth archbishop yorke god forbid man thing earthly enterprise breake immunitie libertie sacred sanctuarie hath bene safegard many good mannes life trust quoth god grace shall neede manner neede woulde shold doe trust shall wyth reason contented thing good manner obtayned happen bring passe yet shal toward far forth best ye shal al wel perceiue lacke denoire mother dreade womanishe feare shall lette womanishe feare nay womanishe frowardenesse quoth duke buckingham dare take vpon soule wel knoweth needeth thing feare eyther hir sonne hir selfe hyr heere man wil warre woman would god men hir kinne woman shoulde soone reste howebeit none hyr kynne lesse loued hyr kinne owne euil deseruing nathelesse loued neither hyr hir kinne yet cause think shoulde hate king noble brother whose grace ourselues kinne whose honour muche desired dishonour muche regarde tooke wealth hir owne shee woulde loath suffer king v haue witte woulde god shee good hathe de witte reckneth hir selfe wiser shee thinketh whose faithfull minde shee nothing doubteth verily beleeueth knoweth woulde sorie hys harme hir selfe yet woulde haue hym hir byde thinke content hir come thence byde suche place maye honor refuse deliuerace follow cousaile whose wisdome knoweth whose truth wel trusteth ethe perceiue frowardnes letteth hir feare go suppose feare may let hir fear hir shadow feareth delyner hym ought feare leaue hir hads caste suche fonde doubt feare hys hurte wil feare shal fetcht thence wyll soone thinke men set god forbid vpon great mischief sanctuarie woulde little lette whiche good men myghte thinketh without sinne somewhat lesse regarde doe nowe shee doubte leaste hee mighte fetched hir likely ynough shall sende hym realme uerily looke none doubte sore mindeth lette thereof might happen bring passe great maistrie letting hir alone world would say wise sorte counfailours aboute king let brother caste awaye vnder nose therfore ensure faithfully minde wil rather maugre hir mind fetch away leaue till hir frowardnesse fonde feare conuey away yet wil breake sactuarie therfore verily sith priuiledges place like haue bin long continued hee would breake good fayth wer begin would shoulde make yet saye naye deede pitie men sea euil dettours haue brought pouertie shold haue place libertie keepe theyr body daunger cruel creditours also crown happen hath done come question whyle eyther parte taketh traytors wil wel place refuge theeues whiche place full neuer fall crafte fall therto pitie sanctuarie shoulde serue muche manquellers god bad take aulter kil murther wilful wher otherwise neede sanctuary god appointed olde lawe eyther necessitie defence misfortune draweth deede pardon serueth whych eyther lawe graunteth course king pitie may looke sanctuarie men whome anye fauourable necessitie compelled goe thyther see tother side sort co monly therin wilful vnthriftinesse hath brought naught rabble theeues murtherers malitious heynous traytours two place specially tone elbowe citie tother bowelsvvestminst saint martin dare well auowe weye good doe wyth hurte commeth yee shall finde much better lacke haue thys saye althoughe abused nowe bee long haue bene feare euer wyll bee whyle menne afrayde sette handes mendmente though god saint peter patron vngracious liuing vnthriftes riot runne debt vpon boldnessethe abuse sanctuary place yea rich men runne thyther poore men good buylde spende bidde creditours go whistle men wiues runne thyther husbandes plate say dare abide husbads beating theeues bring thither stollen good liue thereon deuise newe robbery nightlye steale robbe reaue kill come agayne though place gaue safegarde harme haue done licence also howbeit much mischief wise men would set hand might amended great thanks god breach priuiledge residue sith long ago wote neare pope prince piteous politike hath granted men since certaine religious feare haue broken lette v take payne therewyth let god name stand force farre forth reason wil whiche fully farre forthe may serue let v fetching forthe thys noble man hys honor wealth place whych neyther sanctuarie man sanctuarie serueth alway defende body man standeth daunger abroade greate hurte also lawful hurt vnlawful harmes neuer pope king inteded priuiledge one place priuiledge hath euery place knoweth man place wherein lawfull one man wrong man vnlawfully take hurt libertie k law nature forbiddeth euery place maketh regarde euerye man euerye place sanctuarie man lawfull meanes peryll needeth tuition speciall priuiledge onely ground cause sanctuary necessitie noble prince farre whose loue king nature kindred proueth whose innocencie world tender youth proueth sanctuarie neither none needeth also none haue men come sactuarie come baptisme require theyr godfather must aske must haue reason sith man hath cause haue whose conscience owne fault maketh fayne neede require hath yonder babe discretion require neede dare say would ryght angrie wyth keepe hym would thynke without scruple conscience without breach priuiledge somwhat homely wyth sanctuarie men deede one goe sanctuarie others man good king leauing body libertie satisfie partie good euen wythin sanctuarie neyther kyng pope gyue place suche priuiledge shall discharge man hys debtes able pay dyuers clergie present whither said pleasure thought agreed playnely law god church good sanctuarie man shoulde deliuered payment hys debtes stollen good owner onely lybertie reserued hym get hys liuing labour hys handes verily quoth duke thynke say trueth man wyfe take sanctuarie bycause list runne hir husband woulde weene could alledge none cause may lawfully wythout displeasure saint peter take hir saint peter church arme body may taken sanctuarie sayth byde childe wyll take sanctuarie feareth goe schole hys maister must let alone simple sample yet lesse reason case therein thoughe chyldishe feare yet leastwyse feare herein none verily haue often heard sanctuarie men neuer heard earst sanctuarie child therefore conclusion mynde may haue deserued neede thinke suertie let keepe bee sanctuarie man neyther hath wisedome desire malice deserue whose life libertie lawfull processe stand ieoperdie taketh one sanctuarie doe good saye playnely breaketh sanctuarie duke done temporall men whole good part spiritual also thinkyng hurt earthly ment toward yong babe condiscended effect delyuered fetched howbeit thought best auoyding manner rumor lorde cardinall first assay get hir good therevppon counsell came vnto starre chamber westminster lorde cardinall leauyng protector counsell starre chamber departed sanctuarie queene dyuers lordes respect hys honour shee presence many perceyue thys errande one man mynde protector intended matter trust one man alone else shee finally determyned keepe hym companie happily secrete instruction incontinent maugre hir mynde take leaue hir respite conuey shee lykely mynde matter broken hir hir time would wise serue hir queene lordes come togyther presence lorde cardinall shewed vnto hir thoughte vnto protector vnto whole counsell hir keepyng king brother place thing whych highly sounded onely great rumour people obloquie also importable griefe displeasure king royal maiestie whose grace singular comforte haue hys naturall brother companye dishonour theyrs hirs also suffer hym sanctuarie though one brother stoode danger perill shewed hir counsell therefore sent hym vnto hir require hir deliuerie hym myght bee broughte vnto kyngs presence hys libertie place reckoned pryson shoulde bee demeaned accordyng hys estate shee thys doyng shoulde doe great good realme pleasure counsell profite hir selfe succour hyr friendes distresse uer wiste wel shee specially tendred onely great comforte honour kyng also young duke hymselfe whose greate wealth bee together well many greater cause also theyr disporte recreation thyng lord esteemed leyght though seeme lyghteprotector well pondering theyr youth without recreation play cannot endure straunger coniecture age estate meetely poynt eyther lord quoth queene say nay werethe queen aunsvver ery conuenient gentleman ye require company king brother good fayth mee thynketh great commoditie yet bein custodie mother tender age considred elder specially yonger besides hys infancie also needeth good looking hath beene sore diseased vexed sikenesse newlye rather little amended well recouered dare put person earthly trust keeping selfe onely considering phi tions say also finde double perill recidiuation first sicknesse disease nature beyng sore laboured foreweeried weakened wa eth lesse able beare sustaine newe surfette albeit myght founde would happily doe beste vnto hym yet none eyther knoweth better order hym long haue kept hym tenderly lyke cheryshe hym hys owne mother bare hym man denyeth good madame quoth cardinall grace folke necessarie chyldren would counsel onely content glad ye myght stande wyth pleasure place myght stand wyth honour doe appoynt selfe tarrie heere thynke conuenient duke yorke wyth king honorably lybertie comfort heere sanctuarie man dishonour obloquie sith alway great necessytie haue chylde bee mother occasion may sometime bee expedient keepe elsewhere well appeareth time deerest sonne prince nowe king shoulde honour good order countrey keepe housholde wale farre company grace well content selfe well content quoth queen yet case like one health sicke case maruell greatly lord protector desirous haue hym keeping chyld hys sickenesse miscarrie nature yet myght runne sclaunder suspition fraude call thing sore agaynst childes honour theyrs also bydeth place honor thereto suffer bide man doubteth shall best kepte heere whyle heere yet intende come forth ieoperd selfe friendes would god rather suertie tha ieoperdie madame quoth lord know thing ieoperdie nay verily sir quoth shee shoulde prison neyther bee trowe great maruell though feare least haue letted put duresse without colour let little procure theyr destruction without cause cardinal made countenaunce lorde shoulde harp vpon string said queene nothing doubted lordes hir honorable kynne yet remayned vnder arrest shoulde vppon matter examined doe well ynough towarde hir noble person neyther coulde anye manner ieoperdie whereby shoulde trust quoth queene gyltlesse though giltie enimyes better loued hate sake eere kynne kyng howe farre would helpe god send grace hu therefore purpose yet depart hence gentleman sonne mynde shall bee tyll see assure see men greedie without substantiall cause haue hym maketh much fearder delyuer truely madame quoth fearder deliuer feader bin men suffer keepe least causelesse feare might cause farther conuey many thinke haue priuiledge place neyther haue wyll aske malice deserue therefore recken priuiledge broken though fetche ye finally refuse deliuer verily thinke much dread hath lorde uncle ender loue beareth least grace shoulde hap send away syr quoth queene hath protector tenderthe queene zeale yt feareth nothing least shoulde escape thinketh woulde send hence whych neyther plyght send place coulde recken hym sure sure sanctuarie whereof neuer tyraunt yet diuellyshe durst presume breake trust god strong withstand aduersaries euer sonne deserue sanctuarie therfore haue forsooth hath founde goodly glose place may defend theefe may saue innocent ieoperdie hath neede thereof would god troth protector pray god may proue protector troweth perceyue vnto hys paynted processe draweth honorable duke byde comfortable brother bycause king lacketh playfellowe ye sure pray god send better playfellowes hym maketh high matter vpon tryfelyng pretext though coulde none founde play wyth king hys brother hath luste play sickenesse come sanctuarie safegarde play though prince yong could play rth peeres child coulde playe kinred part agree much worse straungers childe require priuiledge tolde shall heare aske howbeit ga matter suppose coulde aske suppose woulde aske suppose woulde aske goe say shall aske priuiledge selfe say taketh breaketh ye sanctuarie serueth libertie person good ye may hence take horse may take child fro also ward learned counsell sheweth mee sithe hath nothing discent holden knightes seruice law maketh mother gardaine may man suppose take warde sanctuarie without breache sanctuarie priuiledge coulde serue aske himselfe yet sith law committeth custodie may require except law giue childe gardaine onely good landes discharging e safekeeping hys bodie onely landes good serue p example sufficient obtaine priuiledge forthis betvveene marke p marke vvas vvritten englith translated historie vvhich vvrot latten child neede far seeke place questio whether childe may take benefit mine sonne king borne kept cradle preserued prosperous fortune pray god long continue know first time haue taken sanctuarie lorde husbande banished thrust hys kingdome fled hither great childe bare prince lorde husband returned safe agayne victorie went hence welcome home hence brought babe prince vnto father first tooke armes pray god sonnes palace may great sauegarde vnto nowe raigning place somtime ye king enimie place inted keepe brother sith c wherfore intend keepe since man law serueth ye gardaine keepe infant law nature ye mother keepe hir child god law priuiledgeth sanctuarie sanctuarie son sith feare put ye protector hand yt hath brother alreadie fayled inheritor ye crowne cause feare hath man doe examine yet feare farther ye lawe feareth learned tell forbyddeth euery custodie whose death may inherite lesse land kingdome whosoeuer ye breaketh holy sactuarie pray god shortly send neede sanctuarie may come taken sanctuarie woulde mortall enimie lord cardinall perceyuing queene wared euer longer also began kindle chafe speake byting word protector neither beleeued also loath heare said hir finall conclusion woulde longer dispute matter content deliuer duke lordes present durst lay owne body soule pledge onely suertie also estate woulde giue resolute answere contrarie woulde forthwith depart shift would businesse afterwardes neuer intended moue hir matter thought al also saue hirself lacked either wit truth wit dull could nothing perceiue protector intended truth procure hir sonne delyuered handes shoulde perceyue toward childe euill intended queene wordes stoode good greate studie forasmuch hir seemed cardinall ready departe remnant protector himselfe readie hand verily thought shee coulde keepe shoulde incontinent taken thence conuey elsewhere neither time serue hir place determined person appointed thing vnreadie message came hir sodainely nothing lesse looking haue fetcht sanctuarie thoughte nowe beset place could conueyed vntaken partly thoughte might fortune hir feare false wel wiste eyther needelesse bootlesse wherfore needes goe fro deemed best deliuer ouer cardinal faith nothing doubted lordes neither sawe feared least might deceiued wel assured would corrupted thought yet make ye warely looke circumspectly see suertie hir owne hand betooke trust ye last tooke ye yong duke hand said vnto lord lord quoth al lord neither vnwise mistrust wittes suspicious mistrust truthes thing purpose make proofe either lacked mighte turne great sorow realme much harme great reproch loe quoth gentlema dout could keepe safe would whatsoeuer say doubt also abrode deadly enimies vnto bloud wist lay body would let haue also experience ye desire kingdom knoweth kinred brother hath bene ye brother bane may nephewes sure vncle eche childre others defence sunder eche liues lieth others body keepe one safe sure nothing perillous tha one place wise marchant aduetureth good one ship al notwithstading deliuer brother keepe hand shal ask afore god world faithful ye ye wote well knowe well wise power strength keepe list neyther lack ye self lack helpe case ye else may leaue one thing beseeche trust father put euer trust ye put nowe far ye thinke feare much well ware feare far little therwithall saide vnto child farewel mine sweete son god send good keeping let kisse yet ere go god knoweth whe shall kisse together againe therwith kissed blessed turned hir back wept went hir way leauing ye child weeping fast lord cardinal lord wt receiued yong duke brought star chamber protector tooke armes kissed word welcome lord euen wt al hart said ofo dissimulation likelihood thought thervpon forthwith brought vnto king brother bishop palace paules thence citie honorably tower ye day neuer came abrode p protector child handsthis betvveene marke p marke vvas vvritten english translated historie vvhich vvrote lattin opened boldly certaine men also chiefly duke buckingha although know many thought duke priuie al protector cou sel euen fro beginning protector friend said duke first mouer protector matter sending priuie messenger vnto straight k edward death againe knew better subtil wit protector denie euer opened enterprise duke vntil brought passe thing rehearsed whe imprisoned queen kinsfolk gotten hir sonnes owne hand opened rest purpose lesse feare thought meet matter specially duke woon purpose thought strength half increased matter broken vnto ye duke subtill folkes craft master handling wicked deuises declared vnto yong king offended kinsfolk sake euer able would reuenge woulde prick forward thervnto escaped would remember imprisonment else put deathe without doubte yong king woulde carefull deathes whose imprisonment grieuous vnto repenting duke nothing auaile way left redeeme offence benefites shoulde sooner destroy himselfe saue king brother kinsfolkes sawe place imprisoned protector might wyth beck destroy doubt woulde doe deede new enterprise attempted lykely protector prouided priuie garde hymselfe spyalles duke traynes catche shoulde agaynst hym peraduenture least suspected state thing disposition man coulde well tell mighte trust might feare thing lyke beyng beaten duke mynde brought point repented way entred yet woulde goe forthe since begunne woulde stoutely goe throughe therefore wicked enterprise beleeued coulde voyded bent hymselfe went determined since common mischiefe could amended would turne much might owne commoditie agreed protector shoulde haue duke aide make king protector lawfull sonne marrie duke daughter protector graunt quiet possession ledome hertford claimed inheritance could neuer obtayne king edwardes tyme besides request duke protector minde promised hym great quantitie king treasure housholde stuffe thus poynt betweene themselues went prepare coronation yong king would haue seeme myght turne eye mindes men fro perceiuing drift lord sent partes realme came thick solemnitie protector duke sent lord cardinal archbishop yorke lord chauncellour bishop elie lord stanley lord hastings lorde chamberlaine wt many noble men common deuise coronation one place fast another place contriuing contrarie make protector king coucell albeit adhibited secret yet began maner muttering among people though long wel though neyther wyst feared wherefore great thing men harte secret instinct nature misgiue sea without winde swelleth somtime tempest one man happily somewhat perceiuing filled many men suspition though shewed men knew howbeit somewhat dealing self made men muse matter though councell close little little folke withdrew tower drew crosby bishop gate streete protector kept houshold protector resort king manner desolate businesse made sute friend secretly warned might happily turne good muche attendant king without protector appointment remoued also diuers prince olde seruaunts set new thus many thing coming togither partly chaunce partly purpose caused length comon people onely wound wt wind wise men also lord eke marke matter muse thereon farre forth lorde stanley earle darbie wisely mistrusted sayde vnto lorde hastings muche mislyked two seueral councels quoth talke one matter ye one place little wote wherof talke place lorde quoth lorde hastings life neuer doubt one man neuer thence neuer thing moued sound amisse toward shoulde mine eares ere well mouthes ment catesby whiche hys neere secretecatesbie counsell verie familiarly vsed weightie matter put man speciall trust reckening himselfe man liefe sithe well wyste man muche beholden catesby man well learned lawes land speciall fauour lorde chamberlaine good authoritie much rule bare ye countie leycester lorde chamberleynes power chiefely laye surely great pitie eyther truth lesse wit dissimulation onely kept mischiefe vp lorde hastings put speciall trust lorde stanley departed diuers lordes broken daunce many yll signes sawe construes best surely thought coulde harme toward councell intended catesby truth protector duke buckingham made verie good semblaunce vnto lorde hastings kept much companie vndoubtedly protector loued well loth haue lost sauing feare least lyfe shoulde haue quaiied purpose cause moued catesby proue wyth wordes cast farre whether coulde thinke possible winne lorde hastings vnto part catesby whether assayed assayed reported vnto founde fast heard speake terrible word durst breake trueth lorde chamberlayne verye trust shewed vnto catesby distrust began haue matter therefore hee fearing least theyr motion might lorde hastings minishe credence wherevnto onely matter leaned procured protector hastily rid much rather trusted death obtayne muche rule lorde hastings bare coutrey onely desire wherof allectiue induced partner one speciall contriuer horrible treason wherevpon soone wit fryday thirteenth day june many lordes assembled tower sat councell deuising honourable solemnitie king coronation tyme appoynted neare approched pageantes subtiltyes making daye night westminster much vitayle kylled therefore afterward cast away lordes sitting together communing thys matter protector came amongst first ix clocke saluting courteously excusing hymself bene long saying merily bene sleeper day little talkyng sayde vnto byshop elie lorde haue verye good strawberies garden holborne require let v haue messe gladly lorde quoth woulde god better thing readie pleasure therwith hast sent hys seruant messe strawberies protector set lordes fast communing therevpon praying spare little departed thence soone one houre betweene x xj returned chamber among changed wonderfull soure angrie countenance knitting ye browes frowning fretting gnawing lippes sat hym downe place lordes much dismayde sore maruelling manner sodaine change thing aile whe sitten still thus began worthy haue compasse imagine destruction mee beyng neere bloud vnto king protector royall person realme question lordes sat sore astonyed musing much question shoulde ment euery man wyst himselfe cleare lord chamberlaine loue betweene thoughte might boldest aunswered sayde worthy punished heynous traytors whatsoeuer affyrmed quoth yonder sorceresse brother wyfe hir meaning ye queene word many ye lord greatly abashed fauoured hir ye lord hastings minde better content moued hir tha loued better albeit hart somwhat grudged yt afore made counsel matter taking hir kinred putting death assent deuised beheaded pomfret thys self day ware yt deuised yt beheaded ye day london saide protector ye shall see wise sorceresse witch hir counsell shore wife affinitie haue sorcerie witchcrafte wasted body therewith plucked vp dublet sleeue elbow vpo left arme shewed werish withered arme smal neuer thervpo euery man minde sore misgaue wel perceiuing matter quarrel well wist queene wise goe folly also would yet would folke least make shore wife counsell woman hated concubine whome king hir husbande loued also manne present well knew arme euer suche since hys byrth naythelesse lorde chamberlayne death kyng edward kept shore wyfe somewhat doted king lyfe sauing sayde forbare hir reuerence toward k else certayn kind fidelitic friend aunsweared sayd certaynly lord haue heynously done worthie heynous punishment quoth protector thou seruest weene iffes andes tell thee haue done make good thy bodye traytour therewith great anger clapped fyst vpon bourd great rappe token giuen one cried treason without chamber therewith doore clapped come rushing men harnesse many chamber myght holde anone protector sayd lord hastings arrest thee traytour mee lord quoth yea thee traitour quoth protector another let flie lorde stanley shrunke stroke fellthe lorde sta ley vvounded vnder ye table else head cleft teeth shortly shrake yet came bloud eares al quickly bestowed diuers chamber except lorde chamberlaine protector bad speede shriue apace saint paule quoth dinner till see thy head booted aske heauily tooke priest auenture made short shrift longer would suffred protector made much hast dinner might goe till done sauing hys othe brought forth greene besyde chappell within towre head layde downe vppon long logge tymber striken afterward body head enterred windsor beside ye body king edward maruellous case heare eyther warning shoulde haue boyded token coulde voyde selfe night next death lord stanley sente trustie secrete messenger vnto mydnight haste requiring rise ride awaye hym disposed vtterly longer byde hethe lorde stanley dreame hadde fearefull dreame whiche thoughte boare tuskes rased ye head bloud ran shoulder much protector gaue boare cognisance dreame made fearefull impression heart throughly determined longer tarrie hys horsse readie lord hastings would goe wyth hym ride yet farre nighte shoulde daunger ere daye ha good lord quoth lorde hastings messenger leaneth lorde thy maister muche suche trifle hath fayth dreames whiche eyther owne feare fantasieth doe rise nightes rest reason day thought tell plaine witchcraft beleeue dreames whiche token thing come thinketh mighte likely make true going caught brought back friend fayle fleer ye boare cause likelye race v tuskes folke fled falsehoode wherfore eyther peril none deede rather going byding shoulde need cost fal peril one way yet lieffer men see mennes falsehoode thinke eyther owne faulte fainte hearte therefore go thy maister manne commende pray merry haue feare ensure sure manne hee woteth mine owne hande god sende grace sir quoth messenger went waye certaine also riding towards tower morning whiche beheaded horsse twice thrice stumbled almoste falling thing albeit eache man wote wel dayly happeneth mischance toward yet hath bin olde rite custome obserued token oftentimes notably foregoing great misfortune followeth warning enuyous skorne morning ere vp came knight vnto curtesie accompany counsell trueth sent protector hast thitherwardes secrete confederacie purpose meane man time nowe great authoritie knight happened lorde chamberlayne waye stay horsse commune priest mette tower streete brake tale sayde merily lorde praye come whereto talke long prieste haue neede priest yet therewith laughed vpon hym though would saye yee shall haue soone little wist tother mente little mistrusted neuer merier neuer ful good hope life selfe thing often seene signe change shal rather let thing passe vaine suretie man minde neare death upon tower wharfe neare place wher head soone met one hastings pursiuaunt owne name theyr meeting place put remembraunce another time whiche hadde happened meete lyke manner togither place whiche tyme lord chamberlain bin accused vnto king edward lorde riuers queenes brother suche wise lasted long far fallen ye king indignation stoode great feare muche mette pursiuaunt place ieopardie well passed gaue hym great pleasure talke thereof hadde talked thereof place whyle therin therefore sayde ah hastings arte thou remembred met thee heauie hearte yea lorde quoth remember well thanked god got good harme thereby thou wouldest saye quoth thou kn west much knowe whyche fewe knowe else yet mo shal shortly ment lordes queenes kyndred taken daye beheaded ponfraite well wist nothing ware hung ouer heade fayth man quoth neuer sorie neuer stoode great dreade life dyd thou mette lo howe worlde turned nowe stand mine enimies daunger thou mayest happe heare hereafter neuer life mery neuer great suretie good god blindnesse mortall nature feared good suretie reckened surest lost life within two hour thus ended thys honourable man good knight athe description lord hastings gentle greate aucthoritie hys prince lyuing somewhat dissolute playne open hys enimie secrete friend easie beguile good hearte courage forestudied perilles louing man passing wel beloued faithful trustie ynough trusting much flew fame lord death swiftlye citie forth like winde euery man eare protector immediately dinner intending sette colour vpon matter sent hast many substantial men citie tower theyr comming himselfe duke buckingham stoode harnessed olde yll faring briganders man shoulde weene would vouchsafe haue put vpon backes except sodain necessitie constrained protectour shewed lorde chamberlaine conspiracie contriued haue sodainely destroyed hym duke daye counsel intended yet well knowne whiche treason hee neuer knowledge tenne clocke forenoone sodain feare droue put defence suche harneys came next hande hadde god holpen mischief turned vpon woulde haue done thys requyred report euery man aunswered fayre though manne mistrusted matter trothe manne beleeued yet appeasing people minde sent immediately dinner al hast herault armes wyth proclamation made throughe citie thethe protector proclamation kyngs name conteyning lord hastings diuerse trayterous purpose conspired daye haue slaine lorde protectour duke buckingham sitting counsell haue taken vpon rule king realme theyr pleasure thereby pill spoyle whome list vncontrolled much matter proclamation deuised slaunder lorde chamberlayne euil counsayler king father inticing manye thing highly redounding minishing honour vniuersall hurte realme euill companye sinister procuring vngracious ensample wel manye thing dicious liuing inordinate abusion hys bodie wyth manye also speciallye wyth shore wise whiche one also hys moste secret counsaile thys heynons treason laye nightlye namely night last past nexte death lesse maruayle vngratious liuing broughte vnhappy ending whiche nowe putte vnto moste dread commaundemente king highnesse honorable faythfull counsayle bothe hys demerites openly taken hys falslye conceyued treason also leaste delaying execution might haue encouraged mischieuous person partner conspiracie gather assemble themselues togither making greate commotion hys delyueraunce whose hope nowe well deserued death politikely repressed al ye realm god grace rest good quiet peace proclamation made wythin two houres beheaded curiously indited faire written parchment well sette hand therewith selfe long processe euery childe might well perceyue prepared ye time betweene death proclayming coulde skant haue sufficed vnto bare writing alone beene paper scribled forth haste aduenture vpon proclayming thereof one scholemaster paules chaunce standing comparing shortnesse time length matter sayd vnto stoode gay goodly cast foule cast away haste merchaunt aunsweared written prophecie nowe anger couetise protectour sent house shore wife hir husbande dwelled hyr spoyled hir euer aboue value two three thousande marke sent hyr body prison layde vnto hyr manner sake wente aboute bewitch counsaile lord chaberlaine destroy co clusion colour coulde fasten vppon matter layde heynously hir charge thing hir selfe could denye world wist true naythelesse euery manne laughed heare sodainely highly taken nought hir body cause good continent prince cleane faultlesse himselfe sente heauen vicious world amendment men manner caused bishop london put hyr open penaunce going crosse procession vpon sonday taper hir hande whiche went countenance pace demure womanly albeit al array saue hir kyrtle onlye yet wente faire louely namely wondering people caste comely rudde hir cheekes misse yt hir great shame wanne hir much prayse among wer amorous hir bodie curious hir soule manye good folke also hated hir liuing glad see sin corrected yet pitied hir penaunce ethan reioyced therein considered protector procured corrupt intent vertuous affection woman borne london worshipfullye friendedthe description shore vvife honestly brought vp wel maried sauing somwhat soone hir husband honest citizen yong godly good substace much coupled ere wel ripe feruently loued neuer longed happily thing ye easily made hir incline vnto king appetite hee required hir howbeit respect royaltie hope gay apparell ease pleasure wanton wealth able soone pierce soft tender hearte king abused hir anone hir husband honest one could good presuming touch king concubine left hir vp altogither king died lord chamberlain tooke hyr whiche king dayes albeit sore enamoured vpon hir yet forebare hir eyther reuerence certaine friendly faythfulnesse proper fayre nothing hir bodie would haue chaunged woulde haue wished hir somewhat higher thus say knewe hir hir youth albeit nowe see hir yet liueth deeme hir neuer haue bene wel visaged whose iudgement seemeth somewhat like though men gesse beautie one long departed hir scalpe taken charnel house olde leane withered dryed vp nothing left riueld skin hard bone yet euen wel aduise hir visage might gesse deuise part filled woulde make faire face yet delited men much hir beautie hir pleasaunt behauiour proper wit coulde reade well write merrie companye readie quicke aunswere neyther mute full bable sometime taunting without displeasure without disporte obtayned pardon great forfeytures gat men remission finally many weightie sutes stoode many men great steade eyther none small rewardes rather gaye riche eyther content deede selfe well done shee delyted bee sued vnto shewe shee able doe king wanton woman wealthy al wayes couetous doubt shall thinke woman sleyghte thing written set among remembrance great matter whych shall speciallye thinke enioyed knighthoode fielde slaine done earle warwicke ambassade aboute afore remembred mariage thys peere ladie made humble sute vnto ye king might restored vnto small landes hir late husbande giuen hyr ioynture whome kyng behelde hearde hyr speake fayre goodly fauour moderate stature wel made wise pitied hir also waxed enamoured hir takyng hir secretly aside beganne enter talking familiarly whose appetite perceyued vertuously denyed hym wisely good maner word wel set rather kindled desire quenched finallye manye meeting muche wooyng manye greate promise well espyed king affection towarde hyr greatelye encreased shee durste somewhat boldely say hir minde whose heart perceyned feruently set fall worde conclusion shewed playne shee wyste hyr selfe simple wife thoughte hir selfe good hys concubine king muche maruelling hir constancie hee hadde bene wonte else stiffelye sayde naye muche esteemed hir continencie chastitye hee sette hyr vertue steade possession rich thus takyng counsayle desire determined possible haste mary hir thus appointed hadde betweene twaine ensured hir asked counsaile hys friendes suche manner might perceiue booted greatly say nay notwithstanding dutch yorke mother sore moued ther wt ye diswaded mariage much possible mightthe king mother alleaging ye honor profite surety also marie noble progenie realme whervpon depended great strength estate ye affinitie great possibilitie encrease possession coulde well otherwise doe standing earle warwick far moued alreadye likely take wel al voiage wer wise frustrate apointments deluded sayd also yt princely mary owne subiecte greate occasion leading therevnto possession commoditie depending therevpon onely rich man woulde marie mayde little wanton votage vpon hyr person mariage many mo comende maydens fortune maisters wisedome yet therin sayd ther honestie honor mariage much betweene merchaunte owne mayde greate difference betweene king widow whose person albeit nothyng mislyked yet sayde nothing excellent mighte bee founde diuerse meetly quoth shee estate maydens also wheras widowhead elizabeth gray though thing conuenient shoulde yet suffice seemeth refrayne hir mariage sithe vnsitting thing blemishe high disparagemente sacred maiestie prince ought nigh approche priesthoode cleanesse doth dignitie defouled bigamie first mariage king mother sayde made hir aunswerethe king svvere mother part earnest part play merily wyste himselfe hyr rule albeit woulde gladlye take wel yet point minde toke well otherwise howbeit somewhat satisfie hir sayde albeit mariage beyng spiritual thing oughte rather made respect god hys grace enclyneth party loue togtiher trusted hys regarde temporall adua tage yet naythelesse seemed mariage euen worldly considered vnprofitable reckened amitie earthly nation necessarie friedship thought likly beare muche heartie fauour disdayned marie one owne lande yet outward aliaunce thought requisite would finde meanes enter therevnto much better kinne party coulde contented marye himselfe happily neuer loue possibilitie possession lease fruite pleasure alredy smal pleasure taketh man euer hath beside wiued appetite doubt quoth yee saye yt euery point comparable hir therfore let like wedde reason mislike man marry liketh sure yt cousin warwicke neither loueth little grudge loue vnreasonable looke yt shold choyse wife rather ruled eie mine though ward wer boud mary ye appointment gardaine would bea k coditio forbear mine libertie choise mine mariage possibilitie inheritace new affinitie strange land oft occasion trouble tha profite haue alreadie title meanes much sufficeth get keepe well one man dayes widow hath already child god blessed ladie bacheler haue eache v hath proofe nether v like barraine therefore madame pray contente trust god shal king mariage perceyued none impedimente king gret feast honorable solemnitie maried dame elizabeth gray hir crowned queene enimies wife many time prayed ful heartilye losse god loued hir better well spoken said vnto people cleare loude voyce manner wise friendes zeale heartie fauour bearethe duke buckinghams oration wee come breake vnto matter ryght great weightie lesse weightie pleasing god profitable reame part realme profitable citizen noble citie thing wote wel ye haue long tyme lacked sore longed ye woulde haue giuen great good ye would haue gone farre fetch thing come hither bring without labour paine cost aduenture ieoperdie thing certes suertie owne bodyes quiet wynes daughter sauegarde good whych thing tymes paste ye stoode euer doubte woulde recken selfe lorde owne good among many grens trap set therfore among much pilling polling among many tax tallages neuer end oftentimes neede rather grew royot vnreasonable wast tha necessary honorable charge yt dayly pilled fro good honest great substance god lashed among vnthrifts farre forth fiftenes sufficed vsuall manner knowne tax vnder easye name beneuolence good commissioner much euery man tooke man coulde good haue giuen though name beneuolence signified euery man shoulde pay himselfe owne good lyst graunt king good lyst take neuer asked little euery thing haused aboue measure amerciaments turned fine fine raunsoms small trespass misprision misprision treason whereof thinke man looketh shoulde remember example name though burdet forgotten word spoken hast cruelly beheaded misconstruing lawes realme prince pleasure wyth lesse honour markam chiefe justice left office rather woulde assent iudgement dishonestie eyther feare flatterie gaue iudgemet cooke owne worshipful neighbour alderman maior noble citie eyther negligent knoweth forgetful remembreth hard hearted pitieth worshipfull man losse speake losse vtter spoyle vnderserued destruction onely happened fauour prince fauored neede suppose rehearse mo name sith doubt many present eyther themselues nigh friendes haue knowne well good person greatly endaungered eyther feyned quarels small matter agreeued wyth heynous name also crime great could lacke pretext sith king preuenting time inheritaunce attayned crowne battayle sufficed riche man pretext treason haue bene kindred aliaunce neare familiaritie longer acquaintaunce anye tyme king enimies one time halfe realme thus neither good suertie yet brought bodyes ieoperdie beside common aduenture open warre albeitopen vvarre euer occasion much mischiefe yet neuer mischieuous people fall distaunce among themselues none earthly nation deadly pestilent hapneth among v among v neuer long continued dissention many battayles season cruell deadly foughte king dayes deade god forgiue soule whose time whose occasion getting garland keeping leasing winning againe hath cost english bloud hath twice winning fraunce inwarde warre amongciuill vvarre selues hath bene great effusion auncient noble bloud realme scarcely halfe remayneth great enfeebling noble land beside many good towne ransacked spoyled hath bene going fielde comming thence peace long much surer warre time riche men money great men landes feare displeasure perill trusted mistrusted owne brother spared kylled hys owne brother coulde perfitly loue owne brother could manner folke fauored shall honour spare speake howbeit wote well best bare alway least rule sute dayes vnto shore wife vile abhominable strumpet lordes englande except vnto made hir protector simple woman well named honest tyll king hys wanton lust sinful affection bereft hir hir husband right honest substantiall yong man among point good fayth sorie speake sauing vaine keepe counsell thing men knowe king greedie appetite insatiable euery ouer realme intollerable woman yong olde iche poore set eye vpon thing liked eyther person fauour speeche pace countenaunce without feare god respect honor murmure grudge worlde would importunely pursue appetite haue hir great destruction many good woman great dolor husbande friendes honest people themselues much regarde cleannesse house chastitie theyr wiues child leauer lease al haue beside haue villanie done wyth importable dealyngs realme euery part annoyed yet specially ye citizen noble citie well amongest plentie thing minister matter suche iniuryes nearest hand sith neare commonly abyding yet ye people singular cause wel kindly entreat part realme onely prince noble citie hys especiall chamber speciall well renowmed citie oflondon king especiall chamber hys realme much honourable fame receiueth among nation also ye without great coste sundrie peril ieoperdies warres hare euen speciall auour parte whyche kinde myndes borne house yorke sithe hee hathe nothyng worthyly acquited house god grace better shall thing shewe whole summe effecte present errande shall wote well neede rehearse againe ye haue alreadie hearde hym better tell sure ye wyll better beleeue reason bee proude looke therfore yee shoulde recken wordes greate aucthoritie preacher worde god namely man cunning wyse man better woteth shoulde saye thereto good vertuous hee woulde saye thing wyst saye pulpet namely houest man commeth lye honorable preacher yee well remember substantially declared vnto paules crosse sunday last passed right title excellent prince richarde duke glocester protector realme hath vnto bloud sauing set voluptuous pleasure honor ful vmneetly matched minglyng whose bloude togither hath beene effusion great parte noble bloud realme whereby may well seeme mariage well made muche king richarde king richard husht mute one word aunswered therevnto wherewith duke maruellously abashed taking maior nearer hym aboute priuie matter sayde vnto softlye meaneth thys thys people styll syr quoth maior percase perceyue well shall wee mende quoth helpe somewhat louder hee rehearsed matter agayne order wordes well ornately naythelesse euidentlye playne wyth voyce gesture countenaunce comely conuenient euery man muche maruelled hearde thought neuer theyr liues heard euil tale well tolde wonder feare eche lookt shoulde speake first one worde aunswered people stoode styll mydnight muche rowning amongest myght seeme commune best doe maior sawe hee partner councell drewe aboute duke sayde people beene accustomed spoken vnto recorder mouth citie happily wyl aunswere recorder called fitz william sad manne honestfitz vvilliam recorder newe come office neuer spoken people lothe wyth matter begynne notwithstandyng therevnto commaunded maior made rehearsall common duke twice rehearsed himselfe recorder tempered hys tale shewed euery thing duke wordes parte hys owne noting chaunge made people alway one stoode beene men amased wherevppon duke rowned vnto maior sayde maruellous obstinate silence turned vnto people agayne wordes deare friendes wee come mooue thing whiche peraduenture wee greatlye needed lordes thys realme common party might haue sufficed sauing wee sache loue beare much set woulde gladlye doe without thing whiche partner weale honour seemeth either see wey wherefore require giue v answeare one whether yee ininded al noble realm haue noble prince protector king wordes people beganne whisper among themselues secretely voice neither lowde distinct sounde swarme bee tyll last neather end hall bushment duke seruauntes nashfieldes longing protector prentises laddes thrust hall among prease beganne sodainly men backes crye loude theyr throtes woulde gyue king richarde king richarde threwe vp cappes token ioy stoode cast backe head maruelling thereof nothing sayde duke maior sawe manner wiselye turned theyr purpose sayde goodly crye ioyfull heare euerye man one voyce man saying nay wherefore friendes quoth duke since perceiue whole myndes difficultie come vnto first knewe part errand thoughe doubted partly distrusted comming number vnto sodenly without warning knowledge whether came good harme duke shewed vnto maior might therby see little protector looked matter sent vnto messenger suche louing message againe humbly besought vouchsafe might resort presence purpose intent woulde vnto none person part disclose last came forth chamber yet downe vnto stoode aboue gallerie ouer might see speake though woulde yet come neere tyll ment vpon duke buckingha first made humble position vnto behalfe grace ould pardon licence purpose vnto intent comming without displeasure without pardon obteined durst bolde moue matter whiche albeit ment muche honour grace wealthe realme beside yet sure howe grace woulde take woulde wyse offende protector verie gentle himselfe also longed sore witte ment gaue leaue purpose lyked verily trusting good minde hee bare none thing woulde intende vnto warde wherewith ought grieued duke thys leaue pardon speake waxed hee bolde shew intent purpose cause moouing therevnto ye haue heard finally beseeche grace woulde like accustomed goodnes zeale vnto realme nowe eye pitie beholde long continued distresse decaye set gracious handes redresse amendment thereof taking vpon crowne gouernaunce thys realme accordyng ryght tytle lawfully descended vnto laude god profite lande vnto hys grace muche honour lesse payne neuer prince raygned vppon people glad lyue vnder hys obeysaunce people thys realme vnder protector hearde proposition looked verie straungely therat answered albeit ye partly knewe thing alledged true yet entire loue bare vnto king ed child much regarded honor realmes crowne one whiche hee neuer desyrous coulde finde heart poynt enclyne theyr desire nation truth well knowne shoulde peraduenture thoughte owne ambitious minde deuise depose prince take himselfe crowne infamie woulde haue honour stayned crowne euer perceyued much labour payne pleasure hym would vse woulde worthie haue notwithstanding onely pardoned motion made also thanked loue heartie fauour bare hym praying hys sake gyue beare prince vnder hee woulde bee content lyue hys labour counsell farre lyke althoughe yet begonne wherfore would lyke grace take crowne vppon hym woulde humbly beseeche therevnto woulde giue resolute aunswere contrarie woulde lothe heare must needes seeke shoulde fayle fynde noble man would wordes muche moued protectour else euerie man may wit woulde neuer likelyhood haue enclyned therevnto hee sawe none waye eyther must take else hee hys goe sayde vnto lordes common sith englande wherevnto pope ioined honor cardinal thus lyuing many dayes muche honor one man mighte well wishe ended godly death god mercie well changed life man therefore aboute tell long often alternate proofe well prosperitie aduers fortune hadde gotten greate experience verye mother mistresse wisedome deepe insighte pollitique worldly driftes whereby perceyuing nowe thys duke glad commune fed faire wordes many pleasaunt prayses perceyuing processe communication duke pride balke oute little bredde enuie towarde glorye king thereby feeling easie fall oute matter well handled craftely sought wayes pricke forwarde taking alwayes occasion hys commyng keeping himselfe close within bound rather seemed follow leade duke firste beganne praise boast king shewe howe muche profite realme shoulde take raigne lorde morton answered surely lord ollie lye would sweare contrarie lordship would weene beleeue world would haue gone wold haue wished k henry son crown king ed god hadde ordered loose king edwarde raigne neuer madde woulde deade manne striue quicke king edward faithfull chaplaine glad woulde haue bin chylde hadde succeeded howbeit secrete iudgemente god haue otherwise prouided purpose spurre pricke laboure sette vppe god pulleth downe late protector king euen left saying already meddled muche wyth world would day meddle hys booke beades longed sore heare woulde haue sayde bycause ended king sodainely stopped exhorted familiarly betweene twayne bolde say whatsoeuer thoughte whereof faythfullye promised shoulde neuer come hurte peraduenture good woulde weene himselfe intended vse faithfull secrete aduise counsell whiche hee sayde cause procured king haue hym custodie might recken home else bin putte handes whome hee shoulde haue founde like fauour bishoppe righte humblye thanked hym sayde good faith lord loue talke much prince thing perill thoughe worde wythout faulte muche shall taken partie meane pleaseth prince con rue euer thinke esop tale lion hadde proclaymed payne death none horned beast abide wood one forhead bunch flesh led away great pace foxe saw run fast asked whether made haste hee aunswered fayth neuer wote recke wer hence bicause thys proclamation made horned beast foole quoth foxe thou mayst abyde wel ynough lion meant thee none horne thine heade marry quoth hee wote wel ynough call horne duke laughed merily tale said l warrat neyther lio bore shall pike matter thing spoken shal neuer come eares good faith sir sayde bishop thing say taken well afore god meant coulde deserue thankes yet taken weene woulde might happen turne little good lesser longed duke yet muche witte wherevpon bishoppe saide good faith lord late protector sith king possession purpose dispute title weale realme whereof grace hath gouernaunce wherof selfe one poore member wishe good ability whereof hath alredy righte many little needing prayse might yet haue pleased god better store haue giuen excellente vertues meete rule realme lord hath planted person grace left againe duke somewhat maruayling hys sodaynethis follovveth abridged edvvard hall pause saide lorde note often breathing sodayne stoppyng communication intelligence wordes neyther come anye perfecte sentence whereby eyther mighte haue knowledge entente nowe towarde king affection beare towarde comparison good quality ascribed v maketh little muse thinking haue priuie imagination imprinted hearte abashed disclose especially honor assure secrete case deafe dome byshop somewhat bolder considering duke promise moste animated bycause knewe duke desirous magnified also perceyued inwarde hatred whiche bare towarde king richard hee opened hys stomake botome saide singular good lorde sith tyme capti itie whyche beeyng grace custody maye rather call libertie straight imprisonment countrey firste tasted pleasaunte flattering worlde demaundeth debte forgotten whyche saying causeth consider case realme natiue countrey nowe standeth estate assuraunce time hathe cotinued gouernor
